timeline.message:
Add CLA for PXF

Add the Contributor License Agreement and the Contributor Covenant Code
of Conduct files for PXF.

timeline.bodyText: I like to do x git commit --reset --no-edit "--date=$(date -R)" as the action on each commit, so that the commits on master are ordered in time. Not sure how to do this with autosquash, however.
timeline.author: oliverralbertini
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,54 @@
+# Contributing
+
+We warmly welcome and appreciate contributions from the community!
+By participating you agree to the [code of conduct](https://github.com/greenplum-db/pxf/blob/master/CODE-OF-CONDUCT.md).
+To contribute:
+
+- Sign our [Contributor License Agreement](https://cla.pivotal.io/sign/greenplum).
+
+- Fork the PXF repository on GitHub.
+
+- Clone the repository.
+
+- Follow the README.md to set up your environment and run the tests.
+
+- Create a change
+
+    - Create a topic branch.
+
+    - Make commits as logical units for ease of reviewing.
+
+    - Follow similar coding styles as found throughout the code base.
+
+    - Rebase with master often to stay in sync with upstream.
+
+    - Add appropriate unit and automation tests.
+
+    - Ensure a well written commit message as explained [here](https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/) and [here](https://tbaggery.com/2008/04/19/a-note-about-git-commit-messages.html).
+
+- Submit a pull request (PR).
+
+    - Create a [pull request from your fork](https://help.github.com/en/github/collaborating-with-issues-and-pull-requests/.creating-a-pull-request-from-a-fork).
+
+    - We will create a test pipeline which runs additional acceptance tests based on your branch.
+
+    - Address PR feedback with fixup and/or squash commits.
+        ```
+        git add .
+        git commit --fixup <commit SHA> 
+            Or
+        git commit --squash <commit SHA>
+        ```    
+
+    - Once approved, before merging into master squash your fixups with:
+        ```
+        git rebase -i --autosquash origin/master

replies.bodyText: This is not necessary IMO and they cannot merge it anyways. I usually use "Squash and Merge" button from Github, why overcomplicate things ?

replies.bodyText: good point. I think we might provide feedback in the PR. I guess for small commits we might not care too much about provisioning a pipelines, but for bigger features from outside contributors we'll definitely want to provide some feedback and it might not be that simple. How has this been done in the past?
replies.author: frankgh

replies.bodyText: it is tricky as pipelines that run integration tests are not public. I think we can drop this sentence as contributors will expect the feedback on PR and whether we base it on results of some internal pipeline is irrelevant for them if they cannot see it. Also, asking them to write integration tests when there's no easy way to deploy / run them is not ideal, but at least that step is somewhat optional.
